reviews.title: Definitely visit, if only to support them
reviews.text: Africa at its finest, the "National Zoo of Gambia," a few hyenas and baboons—you shouldn't expect anything more, but this is a unique experience. The staff is very happy to have you and does everything they can to make your stay enjoyable. We were the only visitors and received VIP treatment. Definitely worth a visit if you're in the area!

reviews.title: Worth a visit
reviews.text: I think it was a nice walk, although it was at the end of the dry season, and at 37"C!!! We saw several vervet monkeys, the red colobus, a squirrel and an antelope, as well as several birds of all sizes. But the 1.5 liter water bottle was the best.

reviews.title: Very bad experience
reviews.text: Not a good experience. We definitely wouldn't recommend this excursion. Neglected animals and nothing else to see. A waste of time and money.

reviews.title: Disappointment
reviews.text: A carelessly designed national park near Banjuel. The rest areas have probably not been visited in years, the binoculars at the crocodile pond don't work, and the exhibit there is a disgrace. It would be progress if the garbage were cleaned up at least once a day. There are enough staff members, including two Westerners. But they seem to prefer sitting in a circle and discussing things rather than taking action, as we saw. But at least there are several interesting birds and a few monkeys to admire.

reviews.title: Enjoy This Fun Friendly Farm Walk
reviews.text:
The cattle market proved an interesting experience in culture and animal knowledge. Our wise local guide pointed out three types of cattle, from Sénégal, Mali, and The Gambia. Soon we were able to distinguish the breeds.  He gave us info on likely trading prices and the keys to pricing cattle. We also strolled around sheep and goats, and had a great time taking pictures of animal antics. 
This is a great piece of a trip to The Gambia

reviews.title: Not great, pretty run down reserve
reviews.text: Not a great place to visit, there is a “museum” where they try and make you buy something to help with upkeep of the park. There aren’t too many animals there through the forest other than plenty of bugs. The zoo part had 4 sad looking hyenas, a cage full of baboons that looked they were going to break out at any minute and some slightly aggressive monkeys. Overall not great

reviews.title: Well-maintained nature park.
reviews.text: A beautiful and well-maintained forest where you can spot birds with a local guide. There's also one species of wild monkey present, which feeds on their captive counterparts. Hyenas, vultures, and a sanctuary of three monkey species behind a wire fence are also on display.

reviews.title: Nature park
reviews.text: Beautiful peaceful place. Some animals can be seen in their natural environment but you are not guaranteed to see everything as they are free to roam. We had a guide that was very helpful and friendly and at a good price. Staff were not pushy at all and were friendly. Like everywhere in the Gambia you need to negotiate and know what's reasonable. Be prepared to walk but enjoy it.

reviews.title: Terrible living conditions of the animals
reviews.text: Don't go to this park. The animals' living conditions are terrible. Several hyenas are crammed into tiny cages. The monkeys have to fight for food and are crammed into a tiny enclosure with 10 other monkeys. Even if I had known this beforehand, I would never have gone.

reviews.title: Nothing but exploitation
reviews.text: If you are staying at a beach resort, the drive to this place is long, bumpy and polluted. Once there the entrance fee isn't much - but OF COURSE you need a guide. Then they'll try to rent you binoculars. Our guide was nice enough but basically it's a long walk down a path through bushes. That's pretty much it. If you love leaves, knock yourself out. There's a crocodile pool where you won't see crocodiles. There's an 'education center' where a man will ask for maintenance donations stood next to a couple of torn posters that haven't been replaced in 30 years. And of course, next to all this non-learning, there is an 'opportunity' to buy stuff you don't want. Then more walking until finally you get to the world's most depressing zoo - where they'll tell you some thoroughly unconvincing nonsense about why these baboons needed to be in an enclosure rather than just free. Clearly just an excuse to get tourists there and to have them buy peanuts to feed them with. Felt really sorry for them. And there's the three pens with hyenas and vultures co-existing (emphasis on 'existing'). Can't see how anyone but the most ardent fauna and bird fan (not that we saw many of those either) could get anything out of this place. Avoid and do literally anything else.

reviews.title: Peace in the middle of the city
reviews.text: Admission costs 35 D. You don't need a guide. I found the park unspectacular. You basically walk through a forest, pass a lake—I didn't see any crocodiles—and finally reach cages with monkeys and hyenas. The plus point is that it's a quiet oasis in the middle of the city.

reviews.title: Little-visited nature park
reviews.text: Not very big, but definitely worth seeing! Especially outside the enclosures, there's impressive birdlife and—to our surprise—even crocodiles and bushbucks!

reviews.title: A little disappointing
reviews.text: As far as animals go, it's a bit sad. We saw a couple of crocodiles in the water and a few monkeys (most of them in a caged enclosure). There was also an area with vultures and another enclosed enclosure with three hyenas. It's more worthwhile to go see the monkeys in Bijilo Forest, and the crocodiles in Kachically.

reviews.title: You should see it. If this little piece of forest is built on, it will be lost forever.
reviews.text: It's very interesting to have a nature reserve in the middle of a metropolitan area. If you hike through it alone and are quiet (i.e. without a guide), you'll find fascinating animals. You need time. The enclosure is an imposition for me as a conservationist. I didn't even take a closer look. I don't need that. The monkeys disappear immediately when you get closer. But with time and luck, you can see them very close. Unfortunately, I was too late for the birds; you should have been there earlier, around 8 a.m. The entrance fee is 45 dal. A taxi from Serekunda costs 300-400 each way, depending on negotiations and traffic.

reviews.title: Dreadful place - just a way to con tourists. Avoid!
reviews.text: Myself and my partner enjoy nature reserves and also sighting animals and so we believed that this would be the perfect place to visit. We got a taxi there and the taxi driver would wait 2 hours. This was fine. It all went wrong after this! The park is 35D each which is fine but then they are white tourists coming and then the coming starts! Suddenly the price was 370D and forced into having a guide and paying for the taxi driver who wasn't even joining us! Apparently it is too “dangerous” to go without a guide. Then after this rip off we had to hire binoculars for all the birds and wildlife we will be seeing. Another 100D! So far it has cost quite a lot more than expected. First impressions seem run down so I now wasn't expecting much and was annoyed at being ripped off. What followed was a walk with a very sweaty guide with foul body odor who spoke not very good English. What I could make out was mostly about palm trees and the English man who originally founded the park just over 40 years ago. We were taken to the crocodile pool. No crocs to be seen. Disappointing. Two birds in the distance - use the expensive binoculars. Surprise, surprise they don't work! We were then ushered into a dreadful “gift shop” selling over priced junk and almost forced to buy something. With a very poor booklet at 450D we just gave a 200D donation to get out of the room! After this it was a boiling hot walk through a sandy path with more nonsensical waffling from the smelly guide. We saw some monkeys in trees but this was it. The walk led (after what seemed like ages) to an abysmal excuse for a zoo. Hyenas in cages with vultures and baboons in another cage. Such cruel conditions. Some monkeys roamed around wanting to be fed which resulted in another attempt to take money from us. We refused. A man was trying to sell wooden ornaments. I didn't even bother looking at them. Was so disappointed with this place. Luckily the guide didn't demand a tip at the end otherwise the tip would have been - this place needs shutting down.

reviews.title: Dusty.
reviews.text: Indeed, it's a rather dilapidated reserve. A dusty path through somewhat untidy nature. At the end, there are some dilapidated cages with hyenas and a few old monkeys. You can get a drink here, though. There are quite a few monkeys and vultures along the way. Bring water and wear a hat.

reviews.title: Beautiful nature reserve, monkeys crocodiles when they are at home ha ha
reviews.text: But above all, there are many different birds and many rare old African trees. If you love nature, definitely join us. It's easily walkable with simple shoes. Do bring a hat and a drink. Our guide, Babadrammeh, did a great job with illustrations from a book.

reviews.title: Dilapidated reserve
reviews.text: At this time, it's definitely not worth visiting the reserve. If you're unlucky and can't get a taxi to the caged animals, you'll be faced with a boring, sandy path stretching for several kilometers. Once there, you'll see three hyenas, vultures, and four baboons. The taxi driver told me that the government also plans to reintroduce giraffes and buffalo next year. This will certainly increase the "safari" factor.

reviews.title: Island of primeval nature in a humanized environment
reviews.text: My opinion is from the perspective of an ornithologist looking for birds. This is an excellent location for observing some of the most difficult-to-see birds elsewhere, such as the violet and Persian (Guinea, green) turacos. It will take a full day to explore. There's a (small) fee, and you have the option of hiring a local guide at the entrance.

reviews.title: A beautiful park
reviews.text: A beautiful park, the fact is that there are animals in cages but they are animals that were saved from illegal breeders.

reviews.title: In the middle of the "jungle"
reviews.text: With luck, you might see a few monkeys in the distance. The monkeys aren't very friendly. I saw a blue-and-red macaw and a hand-sized spider in the distance. That's about it for wild animals otherwise ;). With luck, you might see crocodiles at the Crocodile Lake. In the middle of the park, there's a monkey cage and a hyena cage. Some of the animals were injured (dominance fights, etc.), and it was generally rather sad to see them there. Some also displayed significant behavioral problems. However, there are free-roaming monkeys at this location, which are also more friendly here. Overall, this is a very beautiful park. Especially if you'd like to walk for a longer time and want a bit of "adventure," this is the place for you. Wonderful nature!

reviews.title: Awful
reviews.text: I can only advise everyone against coming here. It's simply not worth it for the few vultures. The hyenas are behind bars, one of them seriously injured, with an open wound the size of a LP on its back, and no one cares. The baboons were in a crappy enclosure. I don't need to support this kind of thing, and I recommend that everyone not come here.

reviews.title: Bella roseserva un po' in abandonment.
reviews.text: The riserva is beautiful, another occasion for a brilliant passeggiata. But not both the curate and the animals you see are pochisimi. In compensation the price for the income is low.

reviews.title: Ok for a couple of hours
reviews.text:
My wife and I love our wildlife be it birds or 4 legged animals.
The guide from our lodge took us here for the morning.
We visited the large hide and got some great sightings.
There is a shop where you can buy T shirts and other small items, also nearby is a European type toilet, which is clean(ish).
The walk through the forest was easy and most of the pathways fairly wide.
It's then that you get to see the green vervet monkeys. Most stay still long enough for a photograph.
At the end is a very sad and neglected 'zoo'.
A couple of stir crazy hyenas, an adult baboon with a couple of youngsters and some vultures.
In Europe this would have been closed down.
There is a small cafe and some very smelly toilets.

reviews.title: Nice nature park
reviews.text: We went there with our guide, Baxs: a pleasant walk through a jungle path to the central area with a few monkeys and hyenas in cages and a stall with African wood carvings. We saw a few monkeys along the way. We were a bit disappointed; perhaps we were there at the wrong time.

reviews.title: Disappointing (but my own fault).
reviews.text: I visited Abuko after the beautiful canoe trip through the mangroves near Lamin Lodge. It was already past 11 a.m., and the sun was high, meaning high temperatures and very harsh light. I went to photograph the local birdlife, but given the hot weather, I literally saw two swallow-tailed bee-eaters, a pair of lily pads, and a squacco heron. In short: my planning and timing were very poor. Judging by the many beautiful photos on various online nature forums, Abuko is phenomenally beautiful. I'll definitely try it again on my next visit to Gambia.

reviews.title: Fascinating bird reserve
reviews.text: I last came here 8 years ago and it was the highlight of my trip to The Gambia. This time it was still wonderful but there were far fewer birds and rather more people. A good guide is essential

reviews.title: Nothing there now
reviews.text: Been before and was great. Now sadly neglected.  Only hyenas and vultures now. Still a nice walk through forest and a few monkeys to be seen if you are lucky. Only 35 dalasi  to enter and no pressure to take a guide so cannot complain.

reviews.title: Nice walk among the trees, some wildlife
reviews.text: We did the guided wlak, our guide gave some good explanations on flora & fauna. The monleys are not really wild, they expect to be fed peanuts by the tourists. But it makes for some nice pictures/video's. In the animal refuge they make the best of limited means. The hyena's seem mostly OK, I felt sorry for the monkeys behind bars though.

reviews.title: Nice park with a quiet long path and a boat trip along the mangroves
reviews.text: Take a guided tour or visit Abuko Park with Simon Tours. It's not a jungle, but it is a reserve with monkeys (macaques) and beautiful birds. A boat trip on a local boat through the mangroves is a truly unforgettable experience. See beautiful rowers, cormorants, and... the black and white kingfisher!

reviews.title: nature reserve
reviews.text: I went there with higher expectations. The animals—hyenas, two monkeys, and a few vultures—were in cages, just like in German zoos, only under worse conditions. On the way to the crocodiles, we encountered wild monkeys. The crocodile pond and the path to it were okay. Otherwise, not highly recommended.

reviews.title: ЭКЗОТИКА!
reviews.text: В национальный парк Abuko ездили из Кололи на такси. Дорога шла внутрь материка и было интересно увидеть как и где живут гамбийцы. Как только мы вошли в лес и углубились по тропинке в чащу, меня охватил животный страх. Посетителей не было, а из непроходимых, мрачных джунглей веяло холодом, жуть... Я живо представила себе, как что нибудь ужасное сейчас выскочит, выпрыгнет или не дай Бог выползет, но если поднять голову вверх светит яркое  африканское солнце и на фоне голубого неба очень живописно смотрятся разнообразные деревья. Далее мы подошли к вольеру с гиенами. Попали в тот момент когда их кормили, и они с окровавленными мордами бегали друг за другом выхватывая добычу, а над ними... кружила стая грифов. В общем ЭКЗОТИКА, за этим мы и приехали в Гамбию. Рекомендую.

reviews.title: Intressant fågelliv
reviews.text:
Abuko Nature Reserve är väl värt ett besök för den som vill se fåglar. Guiderna är hjälpsamma och hittar många fåglar. 
Missa inte boskapsmarknaden i Abuko innan fågelskådningen.

reviews.title: Upplevelserik  utflykt
reviews.text: Ett väldigt upplevelserik utflykt som ska göras på tidiga morgon runt kl 9,00 eller efter kl 16,00 då plockar aporna nötterna ur händerna och har man tur kommer dom även att sitta på din axel eller arm. terrängen är ej handikapsvänlig efter som det finns branta backar nerför och uppför. under dagtid hamstrar bara aporna mat och ibland bara dom sitter och slappar och sover.

reviews.title: Abuko
reviews.text: Great place to visit but make sure you take water as it gets quite hot as you are walking through. The monkeys are tame, however, they can become aggressive when you are feeding them and the food runs out. Be careful with young children

reviews.title: Monkies and more monkies
reviews.text: Every where I looked I saw monkies.  We took an interesting walk in the reserve and were told about the different vegetation, the history  and the purpose of the reserve. Because I am a city girl the monkies were a delight.  For lunch we were served a delicious meal of african cuisine and entertained with african music and dance.

reviews.title: Distressed animals
reviews.text:
The reserve consists of a fairly narrow strip of land with paths meandering through it. We didn't see much bird life but it's probably there. We did see a few monkey, but not many.
Sadly the "zoo" at the far end has an air of dilapidation or down right abandonment. There are hyena incases that look distressed, one of them just lying there constantly rubbing his muzzle with his forelegs. There were no staff seen at anytime except at the entrance gate. We were glad to leave.

reviews.title: Rather sad to see.
reviews.text: A long trip for not very much.  Such a sad place - yes, there were lots of birds around, but the rewards of seeing and hearing these were more than overcome by the mangy hyaenas (in the same pen as), vultures etc.  I think in a ThirdWorld country this Reserve would be closed down forthwith.  The monkeys were interesting, the cages with reasonable labelling etc.  But, overall, don't waste your time and money.

reviews.title: A good guide is a must
reviews.text: We came here with a guide from our guesthouse, but he only guided us through some paths so we didn't see too much. The park itself is a nice place to see birds and monkeys (we saw more monkeys here than at Bijilo park), I would had liked to stay longer and with a better guide, definitely the park worth it.

reviews.title: Sad reserve
reviews.text: Even though this reserve offers a green setting in the middle of the city, it is unfortunately not a place to encounter wildlife. At a pinch, you will nevertheless come across a few monkeys here and there. At the end of the tour, the sight of caged hyenas and vultures will potentially be unbearable... But it is also by financing the park with our visits that their living conditions can improve. You should go there aiming for a short walk in the cool, under the vegetation, nothing more.

reviews.title: Birds galore!
reviews.text: We visited this nature reserve as part of a birding holiday in The Gambia. We had our own birdguide, Mas Sangeng, arranged by Farakunku Lodges where we were based, however there are guides available to hire at the reserve. Our guide was excellent and we would not have seen half the birds and wildlife without him. The area around the crocodile pool was a bit noisy, some boats were being taken on to the pond and this disturbed any birds there. Green Vervet Monkeys played around the benches and seemed used to visitors. It was further along the pathways we started to encounter the more interesting birds, Green and Violet Turaco, Western Bluebill and African Paradise Flycatcher to name just a few. With patience and a good guide the possibilities are endless. We had no interest in visiting the "zoo" preferring to spend our time looking for birds and we were not disappointed.

reviews.title: Not seen much
reviews.text: Visited and walked through. Heard lots of animals but didn't see them until my husband opened the zipper on his backpack. There were the monkeys. Personally, we would have preferred to skip it on our tour. We walked without a guide.

reviews.title: So cool...so many monkeys in a beautiful park
reviews.text: It was great in 2014...Very cheap. Our guide took us along the nicest paths...so we saw lots of monkeys.

reviews.title: Better places else where
reviews.text:
Pretty poor attraction. As said before, the animals caged at the back of the reserve are poorly maintained and look unhappy.
Go else where!

reviews.title: Ei paljoa nähtävää
reviews.text: Odotukset olivat korkeammalla kuin mitä tämä paikka tarjosi. Nähtiin muutamia apinoita ja korppikotkia. Taukopaikalla kerättiin rahaa puistolle, mikä oli toki tapa muissakin nähtävyyksissä. Puiston toisella puolella oli häkissä hyeenoja, papukaija ja jokunen apina, jotka kävivät sääliksi.

reviews.title: A nice walk, but not much else. . .
reviews.text: Situated on the side of the airport road to Serekunda and the beach resorts, the park is easily reached by taxi from most hotels, and is an ideal 'on your own' half day out when you have exhausted your tour operators organized trip portfolio. The self-appointed title 'Nature Reserve' does however raise the expectations of the first time visitor, which are unlikely to be met, hence the string of negative reviews. On arrival, first stop is the ticket hut, where you are relieved of a modest 35 Dalasi each . . . so far so good. You are then directed to an open hut where several 'guides' are waiting. We told them we had been before and were happy to go unaccompanied; the reply is 'snakes sir; lots of snakes. . . if you don't know where to look, very dangerous'. The guides were all wearing combat trousers tucked into high laced army boots while I was wearing M&S linen shorts with a pair of Reeboks; I figured they may well have a point. In an act of extortion that The Peaky Blinders would be proud of, we were instantly relieved of a further 300D, but they had not finished yet . . . 'you will need binoculars' they tell us, and whoosh, another 100 changes hands. What follows is in essence a very nice walk following a well worn path through shady and peaceful woodland, a few birds along the way but nothing you won't see around your hotel, an army of ants crossing the path, some epic spider's webs, but not much else. Next stop is the natural lake containing several hard to spot crocs; you are led up wooden steps to an observation platform which doubles up as a gift shop; another hard sell along the lines of 'the park runs on donations and what the tourists spend'; we were in need of a few trinkets for nieces back home, but unfortunately the variety of gifts was on par with the variety of wildlife, and we escaped wallet intact and empty handed. Another meandering walk with more of the same; 20 years ago, the path was lined with monkeys, eager to be fed with the bananas that were sold at the entrance; no bananas this time, and no monkeys; there is now a snack stall at the enclosures, and the monkeys learned very quickly that simply hanging around here will keep them well fed with the minimum effort. They have however become very spiteful and greedy, and will quickly snatch the newly purchased bag of monkey nuts from your hand. The photo opportunities are there, if not a little predictable and staged, and short of a few hyenas in a large pen not much else here to detain you. Exit is via another walk along another path, and is a different place to your drop-off, but your taxi driver will know this and be waiting for you. A gift shop is at the exit, giving another couple of desperate women one last opportunity to mug you before you disappear forever. The guide then hints heavily that he is not paid and relies on tips; you say I have already paid 300, he says yes but I don't get that, we part with one final 200 for the guide and find our taxi. We asked our driver to stop off at Lamin Lodge on the way back for a lunch break; we then detoured back via the pharmacy for a few bits, then the mini market for a few more; all in all, a good half day away from resort, but a nice shady walk only; no more, no less. Hugely overpriced for what it is; (we spent 670D plus coke and monkey nuts); better opportunities locally to resort for both monkeys and crocs, and at a fraction of the price. Don't expect too much; don't bother with binoculars, and ditch the guide if you can.

reviews.title: Don't bother coming from the beach resorts
reviews.text: I happened to be staying nearby waiting for a flight so spent the morning walking around the reserve. Don't expect to see any wildlife except birds and a couple of monkeys. The animal "orphanage" is really depressing and the guides let a tourist get in the enclosure with two hyenas which makes me think they have no idea how to deal with and treat animals. I only gave two stars because the forest itself is quite nice to walk around and I came with low expectations but I had the opportunity of taking a day trip from one of the beach resorts earlier in my holiday and I'm really glad I didn't

reviews.title: Absolutely awful
reviews.text: I went there with a friend last week (2/12/17) We went equipped with a book of birds, binoculars, 'it aint half hot' outfits etc expecting to see wild birds in their natural habitats etc. There were no birds at all. Only a few baboons and a couple of wolves like creatures in cages and that, as they say, was that. This is a classic case of a really good bloke who had a dream once that was realized and when it was created and nurtured, it must have been fabulous. Now, it is a ghost town birdwatching place with no birds but just bumsters having taken over what was once probably something worth seeing. Don't go. There is nothing here to see. The local chancers have taken what's left of a dream over and the place is a shell. There is nothing to see. Really. Don't waste your money. Don't do it. This is a vacuum dump.

reviews.title: Dubious interest to a casual tourist
reviews.text:
I've visited this site several times in search of birds.  Whilst home to many species (some of them very rare) they are not easy to see in the forest, and I'm not convinced that this is a location that a casual tourist would enjoy.  If you do go, make sure you take your insect repellent!

The "animal orphanage" is a central element of most visits, but the conditions under which the animals and birds are kept are really depressing.

reviews.title: Bird paradise
reviews.text: A beautiful forest, you can really see how diverse nature can be. Lots of birds, especially the crocodile pool, which is a wonderful spot to watch. I found the animals in the cages rather sad, so I deliberately skipped them.

reviews.title: Disappointed!
reviews.text: We had previously visited other reserves in Gambia and this one disappointed us. We paid extra for a guide and another extra to rent binoculars. As a result, we didn't even use the binoculars because we didn't see any birds. The only animals we saw: A cobra in the distance (only one of us saw it), a crocodile, and a few monkeys in the trees. Halfway through the visit, we saw hyenas and vultures locked in an enclosure... It was difficult to understand the guide. During the visit, he spent his time with his nose on his phone. Positive points: the place is easy to find and it will make for a pleasant walk under the trees.

reviews.title: Wonderful forest to walk through
reviews.text:
Abuko nature reserve isn’t like the big safari parks.

There isn’t any big wildlife here but there’s plenty other stuff to see and check out.

The walk itself takes about a good hour and it’s best to bring water and avoid the high noon. 
We saw some of the big lizards, monkeys and beautiful spiders. It is said there are some cobra an python snakes as well in the area but you’ll have to be lucky.

Halfway the walk there is this big tree with vultures. Loads of them sitting there. Best not stand underneath them too long...😁

The Hyena’s aren’t there anymore and neither the crocodile. They have been replaced.

As it is with nature parks...you can be really lucky, or really out of luck.

With an entrance fee of 40 dalasi each it’s worth a shot!

reviews.title: Don't waste your time without a knowledgable and private guide
reviews.text: This is a good reserve if you are really interested in exploring the nature and go without any set expectations. There is no point going there just to tick the box on the places you visited. You need a clean, experienced and knowledgable guide with you to enjoy this park. I do not recommend taking "any" guide at the park as most of them are useless. Also do not go in large groups as you will scare the animals out and will only be able to see the ones in the cage. You need to have a lot of patience and stamina to walk for at least 90 minutes. The best time to visit is in the morning when the sun is not heavy on you. We went during the rainy season so it was a different experience altogether. However, the walking paths were a bit muddy and we had to be extra careful but we thoroughly enjoyed our outing. We had an excellent guide with us who was very knowledgable and knew everything about the park. He was our private guide, not costly at all. If you are visiting this country then spend a little extra it will be worth the experience you get compared to others. We saw many beautiful birds on our way as well as lots of red monkeys. They are very shy of humans so make sure you do not make any noise when you spot them. It is a treasure to see them jumping from the tree branches or just sitting over there. We spotted two chameleons and our guide said that you must be very lucky to have them. He got one of them before it ran away and put them on a stick and handed it over to us. We could see it changing colors before we let it go free in the wild and had enough of pictures with it. The experience with Hyena was great as well as this was the first time I saw them and so close. They do look dangerous but we had a Ranger protecting us while we take our picture with them having behind us in the close proximity. The Rangers will be quite supportive if you go with a known guide and that is the difference. They too will share a lot of knowledge with you. Eventually, you need to be friendly and taking interest and then everything else will automatically fall in place. Don't be like another tourist.

reviews.title: Nice to see but...
reviews.text: Nice to see, but not particularly spectacular. It's a good half-day tour, and perhaps especially interesting for bird lovers, as there are so many different species. Here you'll see hyenas, vultures, baboons, and so on. It's also not very large; you can easily cover it in 45 minutes. And you can't touch hyenas everywhere, but you can here.

reviews.title: Abuko
reviews.text: The national reservation abuko is nice place to visit during your stay in gambia despite there is not so much to see , but you can go inside the cage with hyena for example so good place for brave people.

reviews.title: Birdwatching with Mustapha Barry
reviews.text: One of the first trips I made was Abuko nature park. I was with Mustapha Barry,birdwatching guide, i was amazed by his knowledge about birds and nature, We had a nice walk and he spotted the most butiful birds like the violet and green Turaco, red-billes Hornbill,swallow-tailed Bee-eater and many more. Also different kind of monkeys. It was a very nice experience especially to do it with Mustapha Barry and I can recommend him as being honest,reliable and driver with his own 4x4 car. You can contact him at Kotu Bridge or by telephone (+220) 7165867

reviews.title: Birdwatching
reviews.text: Abuko was the first natural area officially designated as a protected nature reserve, three years after Gambia's independence in 1965. It's one of the smallest parks in all of West Africa. But biodiversity is high. Along the marked trail within the park, which encompasses less than 200 hectares, you'll quickly transition from sparsely vegetated savannah into dense, verdant tropical rainforest. Thirty-meter-tall palms and mahogany trees surround you in the heart of the park, their evergreen foliage partially blocking out the bright sunlight. Abuko is a prime spot for birdwatchers. So be sure to bring your binoculars and enjoy watching the hundreds of birds flutter by. Visit the Makasutu Wildlife Trust, a research center dedicated to studying Gambia's biodiversity.

reviews.title: Forest walk
reviews.text: A forest walk, ending with a visit to the three baboons and five hyenas. Nothing special, but it was a nice walk!

reviews.title: Nice forest but sad caged animals
reviews.text:
The forest itself is a nice and peaceful place where you can see some animals in their natural habitat. Even some rare elusive red monkeys may be seen. You can spend a relaxing hour or two walking the trails and listening the nature.

However, there are some caged animals, such as hyenas and baboons, where the trails start. They didn't seem to be doing very well and had very small space to move around in their cages.

reviews.title: Abuko
reviews.text: When we first got there the guy behind the desk was so ignorant and wouldn't answer us and when he did he had such a bad attitude. Went around the park with a guide, very long walk, saw a few monkeys but he only really showed us trees and termite mounds, didn't see no birds, snakes or crocs. He took us to the baboons and explained they are in cages as they are violent... Went to see the large vulture that flew down from its perch to us, loads of other vultures flying about in the area. Went inside the hyenas den which was definitely an experience especially when they started walking towards us and wanting us to rub them like dogs and trying to play. I didn't know hyenas could be friendly!! Then on leaving the park there is a massive hippos head on display, the guide said they killed the hippo as he was eating the locals rice fields, told him it's cruel and sick for keeping the head on display, he didn't agree.... The park has potential to be better and house more animals as it did a few years back but they need to make sure animals are taken care of and I don't think tourists will appreciate seeing a rotting hippo head!! Apart from that, nice few hours out and a lot of walking.

reviews.title: Stunning bird life
reviews.text:
West African Reserves are not to be compared with the Wild Parks of  East Africa or
Botswana. The main attraction of Abuko are the rare Red Colobus Ape and the truly stunning birdlife, so the best thing to do is to stroll the Reserve accompanied by a good bird guide. There are two hides available for birders.

reviews.title: Two hides available and assisted our photography out of the sun.
reviews.text: If you are bird watching or photographing then this is a must visit sight. We saw a good number of species including green and Violet Turacos along with giant Kingfishers.

reviews.title: Not many animals!
reviews.text: We had a nice walk round the park, but did not see any animals, and not many birds. Maksutu Cultural Forest or the monkey park near Senegambia were more fun.

reviews.title: Caged animals in awful conditions
reviews.text: The 'protected' forest itself is very disappointing and most of the animals have left, bar a few monkeys. We walked through the forest with a guide but there really was nothing to point out. At the end you come to a 'rescue' center. There are caged vultures, monkeys, tortoise, pelicans (all in one cage) and loads of uncastrated hyenas in others. Not a nice experience at all and sadly the 'staff' couldn't understand why we thought it was cruel and that this wasn't something that tourists wanted to see. Very sad! Please don't visit!

reviews.title: Interesting place
reviews.text: This place is beautiful if your after a sedate but long nature walk with lots of birds and monkeys. The animal orphanage needs some tlc and some education on environment and animal rehabilitation but they are making the best of a bad job! It is worth a visit especially if you see the endangered west red colobus monkeys.

reviews.title: Amazing monkeys
reviews.text: Great place to visit although quite a long walk. The monkeys are wonderful to see but the other animals in the cages don't seem quite as happy although still well looked after.

reviews.title: An Amazing Area of African Forest Close to Banjul
reviews.text: This nature preserve/research station/wild animal rehabilitation site is a must visit for anyone interested in the natural history of Gambia.  The trails are safe and easy to follow, but be careful not to stop on/near a stream of ants on the move.  Local experts are available to guide birders and further information is available at the observation deck of the Darwin Research Station.

reviews.title: Day trip
reviews.text: Beautiful place to visit for young and young at heart, monkeys were amazing, a little greedy but very friendly 😁

reviews.title: EVERYTHING IS VERY DIRTY
reviews.text: There were lots of monkeys, but this park is completely neglected. Everything is full of trash, and the staff shows no interest in the visitors.

reviews.title: A simple forest reserve
reviews.text: You can see only voltures and Monkeys and a few hyaenas. It may be a good idea to take a walk with a guide. It is a different place in the Gambia.

reviews.title: Small but nice.
reviews.text: The nature is beautiful, and you can take a lovely walk and spot many birds. There's also a kind of mini zoo with some lovely animals, like hyenas. Many people have commented on how awful they find the animals in cages, but it's not much different from a zoo in our home country. The guide also told us that many animals are here to form a new group of males and females, hopefully to live in the wild again.

reviews.title: A nice place to walk but I don't want to see anyone in cages
reviews.text: Most of the Abuko park is nice and the monkeys are free, but there's also a part where they keep some monkeys and even an eagle in cages! The cages are too small and they do not seem to have a nice and happy life. I don't think that such intelligent creatures should be held in a prison and it made me sad to see that. But if you skip the zoo part you might enjoy it, because it's a really nice place for a walk. They don't want to let you go inside without a local guide, but don't mind them, you won't get lost! If you get a guide, you need to pay for the entrance fee and also some tip to the guide - not worth it. You'll see the monkeys and lots of birds anyway :)

reviews.title: Interesting venue
reviews.text: We have visited a couple of times on our way to and from other attractions.  Interesting  walk and park even for those who are not serious bird watchers.  Also a small zoo.

reviews.title: Nothing outstanding but a nice nature walk
reviews.text: We visited this park along with Lamin Lodge on a tour from Kololi. They insisted we paid for a tour guide to take us through the park, the guide was very uninformative, not really talking to us or telling us about the park but simply trying to get around as quickly as possible the forcibly asking for a large tip. It would have been much nicer to simply take our time and wonder through the reserve. It was generally a pretty reserve and we did see some green vervet monkeys who were quite happy to have their photo taken but if this is what you are looking for then Bijilo park is a much better nature park with more monkeys and just as nice/nicer scenery. There were Baboons and Hyenas in cages in one section but I tend not to like seeing animals unnecessarily in cages so did not find this an enjoyable part of the park. They had also had a hippo there which had died recently and they kept its head on display (not pleasant to look at!) We had a nice day but I didn't think this park and any advantages about Bijilo

reviews.title: Birdwatching but few wild monkeys
reviews.text: Birdwatching is fun, but not a whole lot to see! Lots of vultures. Nice nature walk. Saw some monkeys in the wild. Hyenas and monkeys locked up...

reviews.title: Sad to see these animals behind ugly mesh.
reviews.text: We visited this park with a private guide at the end of the day. We were allowed to drive to the hyena enclosure. We saw the hyenas in a large enclosure behind double layers of chicken wire. In another enclosure were a few monkeys, a young deer, a tortoise, and a vulture. Several monkeys were able to move around freely. We weren't impressed with this place. Now that I look at the photos, I think our guide missed a lot.

reviews.title: Book a Guide Before You Go
reviews.text: As much as I wanted to visit Abuko I was almost put off by some of the things said in the negative reviews but we were booking some bird watching trips with a bird guide and he assured us it was an important place to visit. He wasn't wrong! Our very informative guide, Musa Manneh (+220) 7834098, showed us a total of 51 different species of wonderful colorful and spectacular birds that day along with an abundance of information about the various plant, insect and animal species we were seeing along our walk. Although he is predominantly a bird guide he is very knowledgeable about the natural history of Gambia and will give insights into the local culture too. It is very evident to me that the way to get the best out of this place is to arrange with someone who understands it to take you there. Avoid booking a trip with a mini bus full of people, you will disturb any wildlife as the mass of people tramp through the well trod paths of the reserve. Individual guiding is not as expensive as you might imagine in The Gambia and it pays massive dividends in how much it improves your experience of these places. You only have limited time during your holiday so why waste it by handing a poultry sum to a bumster who will walk with you but not give you any insight or understanding to the things you are seeing and not help you to see the things that prefer not to be seen! During our time there so many people walked right past us as we were standing watching some magnificent bird, once or twice people would stop to look in the direction I was pointing my camera lens and we would point out what we were seeing. A guide you have employed to take you there will ensure you avoid unwelcome advances from the bumsters and ensure you are proceeding at a pace that suits your stamina and ability, at least that is what we experienced with Musa. We set off early so we could avoid being there at the hottest time of the day. Musa also took us to explore an area of paddy fields opposite the reserve before we went in and that area was simply amazing. If anyone wished to book him before they leave home then they can do so via email musaamanneh56@yahoo.com and you can find his website by typing Musa Manneh Bird Watching Tours into your search engine. The man is a gentleman who will provide a car with a very safe driver and take great care of you, he speaks perfect English too.

reviews.title: Great Photo opportunities
reviews.text: We visited Abuko as part of trip with Arch tours and really enjoyed it, great photo opportunities for bird watching and general wildlife.  We saw loads of different birds including a giant kingfisher. At the end of the trail is a small zoo area which has baboons and Hyenas, however this is not best part of reserve.

reviews.title: Not worth it
reviews.text: It was included in a tour package but not recommended... Nothing to see... Only a few monkeys in a cage at the end.... Too bad, not recommended

reviews.title: a long walk to a small zoo
reviews.text: Abuko costs very little to get in - less than £1. The guide didn't really talk to us so we gained little from having him. Essentially you walk a long way to see animals in cages - not what we expected. Although the animal keepers took us inside the hyena pen which was pretty amazing. Then the long walk back and pushy market sellers on the way out - you have to be firm if you don't want to buy! Much preferred bijilo park.

reviews.title: More fun than the zoo
reviews.text: Had a wonderful trip to Abuko. We used the "tanka tanka," which means constantly switching to local taxis that travel back and forth between fixed points. Dirt cheap. A local guide is recommended. It's worth negotiating the price. Take your time, as it's also a wonderful area for hiking. Don't expect too much from the animals. You'll definitely need a guide to see them. As for potentially dangerous animals like the hungry crocodiles, I'd say: you'll need one to spot them in time!

reviews.title: Scam
reviews.text: Just a word of warning,the so called guides at Abouko have nothing whatsover to do with Abouko Park,they are just chancers or 'Bumsters' if anyone cares to look at earlier previous posts it will be explained in more detail there,since the funding for the park was stopped a few years ago all the official guides are well gone. If your putting money in a box at the lodge next to the so called croc pool that goes straight into the bumsters pocket. Regarding 'Eagle Heights' with the Lion Cubs,Cheetahs etc (all poisoned) it was a front for a bird of prey import scam to the UK, which is well documented on Facebook.

reviews.title: Poor quality zoo with some wild monkeys.
reviews.text: Situated just outside town this reserve is said to host “displaced” animals in an attempt to help preserve Gambia's wildlife. There are plenty of sightings of Vervet Monkeys which are well habituated to humans (they can be very amusing) and some Red Colobus Monkeys are also present. But essentially it's really just a small open air zoo. A troop of Baboons is kept in a fairly spacious enclosure, with a couple of cages Hyena nearby to the drinks stall. People tell of ongoing improvement work, but there was no sight of actual improvement on the ground since 2012, and considerable degradation since that visit. Worth a visit - I don't think so.

reviews.title: Nice walk
reviews.text: Visited here with my gambian boyfriend, my son and another couple. I thought it was a really nice walk and plenty of animals to see. I particularly liked the fact that the majority of them were free to roam around.

reviews.title: Excellent place to see birds, crododiles and small mammals
reviews.text: If you like nature, this is a must see in Gambia. In particular the view point on the little lake was marvelous with its many birds and crocodiles. We saw several monkeys. There are fierce looking hyenas in a separate fenced area.

reviews.title: A lot has changed in a year
reviews.text: The park was a good day out last year with hyena, cheetahs, a lion cub and monkeys, however in the past year both cheetahs and the lion cub have died raising my concerns. The monkeys and hyenas are still nice to see though

reviews.title: A bit of diasapointing
reviews.text: We went here by taxi and a guide was waiting for us to show us around. The guide seemed to be in a rush and didn't take time to tell you anything about the park. We saw some monkeys but you can see them in many places around. There are some hyenas and other types of monkeys but they are caged and seemed to be very bored. It is easy to find your way around the park, a guide is really not needed, so I would save the money next time.

reviews.title: Great for bird watching
reviews.text: Hundred of birds to chase with a camera and tripod or a telescope. You are welcomed by monkeys then as you walk trough the forest, you can enjoy the beauty of the jungle as it is, with birds and lizards and butterflies and crocs. You definitely need a good guide, not for not getting lost but for information about the birds, trees and everything.

reviews.title: If you are a birdwatcher, you can't miss it.
reviews.text: The reserve, despite being somewhat abandoned and looking run-down, is a highly recommended spot for nature photography and birdwatching enthusiasts. In a single morning, you can see several dozen species of African birds. The ideal thing is to be at the gate early in the morning and enter as soon as the door opens. It's a shame to see the hyenas in their cage in poor condition. Otherwise, highly recommended.

reviews.title: Waste of time
reviews.text: Since Abuko was included in a tour, we went there with our guide. But it was a waste of time. There's no wildlife, unless you consider the captive baboons, vultures, and hyenas wild. These animals are confined in cages that are far too small. It's inhumane. There's supposed to be a stray crocodile in the pond, but we didn't see it. If you don't visit Abuko, you won't miss anything.

reviews.title: Interesting but not worth a return visit.
reviews.text: Their information centre needed updating when we were there four years ago -perhaps that has happened by now?  The monkeys were engaging but the crocs were a bit shy and hiding away when we looked  for them,

reviews.title: A few monkeys and the rest behind bars
reviews.text: There are some monkeys, but you'll see them elsewhere too. The antelopes have already been eaten by the surrounding villages (according to our guide), the crocodiles are always underwater (yes, indeed), and the baboons and hyenas are locked in far too small spaces or cages—a horrific spectacle. You'll walk quite a distance (not suitable for small children or the elderly) and see almost nothing. In short, stay away!

reviews.title: Perhaps Not A Fair Review
reviews.text: A taxi driver took me here recently only to be told when we arrived that the place was closed. He was surprised to hear this. However, I spoke a few days later with a different, experienced taxi driver that I have done a lot of business with, and he explained to me that many of the animals that had been there had died, which is why they had to close their doors. I am not sure what happened and I am not sure when they will be opening again but I thought I would post the information I was giving here for other people who might be planning to visit Abuko.

reviews.title: all'abbandono!!
reviews.text: piccola riserva nel cuore della citta', che purtroppo nel corso degli ultimi anni a mio avviso e' stata un po' trascurata e lasciata all'abbandono. Communicate a good opportunity to take a walk in nature, with the possibility of seeing diverse types of animals... all with a very low price.

reviews.title: Beautiful
reviews.text: Lovely walks through forest, chance to see Crocs in the Lake, and in the center they had free roaming monkeys who came and happily took peanuts from your hands, and anything in your pockets was lovely. My best experience was befriending a young baboon there, he was very friendly and affectionate and was a delight seeing him playing with the other Monkeys. They had hyenas there, vultures and a little place to get a bite to eat. Easily spend a couple of hours there. You can take a guide or go in on your own, easy to find your way around doing it alone. Truly loved it!

reviews.title: Money scam
reviews.text: I had an experience very similar to that of zippideedoodle below. My group and I (consisting of Gambians and Europeans interested in conservation and wildlife) had wanted to explore the park freely for the local wild nature. We were pressured into hiring a guide who was not overall very informative but did point out some different species, The guided then took us out a side gate to Eagle Heights, without informing us this is what was happening. He wanted us to pay another guided to show us some of the animals they have there - an experience we didn't even want. We did not pay and got walked back along the road to the entrance of the nature reserve. It could have been a very different experience.

reviews.title: Tinham aninhais no parque ?
reviews.text:
Tive oportunidade de visitar outros dois parques nesta viagem: Bijilo Forest Park (Gâmbia) e Fathala (Senegal).
Em qualquer um destes vemos mais e mais bem tratados animais

reviews.title: monkey park - fab
reviews.text: went for a day at the monkey park.  You aren't supposed to feed the monkeys but our guide got us bags of nuts.  the monkeys jump on your shoulders and take the nuts out of your hand.  very friendly and cute. well worth a visit there.

reviews.title: Good walk round but be aware that the English owners charge Europeans more for entry.
reviews.text: Visited in Feb 2015 and enjoyed Abuko very much having a walk round and feeding the monkeys. Seeing the lion was nice as was the birds and snakes all in all was worth the money.

reviews.title: Like and big park
reviews.text: For many years ago it was a nice place where they had names on evert special trees and there were so many different animals there, but now I'm disappointed because it's mostly apes and births there now day. It's like the forgotten place where they just send tourists for having anything to do. If you want to go there take your time early in the morning or around 6 in the evening. Then you will have a chance to see some of the animals.

reviews.title: Not what is advertised
reviews.text: Went here paid 900 dalasai and saw none of the cheetah or lion or orphaned animal advertised on the pamphlet. Don't know if there are 2 eagle heights but definatly not what is advertised on their pamphlet. There was some old hyenas and a few monkeys caged up. Guide was quite good in pointing out birds and wildlife but as per usual in Gambia expects a tip.

reviews.title: Abuko and Eagle heights conservation reserves
reviews.text: Seeing the monkeys and crocodiles different bird's and hyena and going to Eagle heights conservation area where they are trying to breed the cheetah that they bought over with them from their park in Kent England not far from where we live.... And seeing the beautiful lion cub Buba and hope that next time we visit we see it in a lovely natural enclosure and possibly with a mate....

reviews.title: Worth a Short Trip, but Don't do 2 hours
reviews.text: Parts of this place are very cool, such as what they called the orphanage where you can see hyenas and lots of monkeys. Other parts are a bit boring. I would recommend having your car take you all the way into the orphanage rather than doing a 1 or 2 hour walk around the reserve. You can buy peanuts or bananas to feed to the monkeys at the orphanage, and that was quite fun.

reviews.title: overrated
reviews.text: We went, payed 400 dalasis each and 200 for a guide who did not tell us much. Just walked arround. Didn't spot a lot of birds but we didn't go at the good birdtime :) and if there were any our guide did not point them out. Also went to the zoo, there was a lion in a really really small cage. The birds were strapped and couldn't fly so i didn't like it!

reviews.title: Nice nature park, but don't see it as a safari
reviews.text: A beautiful and charming nature park with a large pond containing a crocodile. The locals can also tell you about the snakes, other animals, and trees. The new bird show, performed by English people, is also well worth a visit.

reviews.title: Warning! Reserve Now Occupied by Unmonitored Scammer Bumsters!
reviews.text: The Abuko Nature Reserve is a large forest protected by the Government of The Gambia. It was once developed and maintained by the University of Warwick in the UK as a Darwin Field Station for biodiversity study, a project that ended in 2005. Since then, the developed portions of the Reserve have been abandoned and taken over by "bumsters" who know nothing about nature or biodiversity, but have figured out a number of scams to take your money. For example, the true entry fee for the park is 15 Dalasis as shown on the official receipt you are given...upon payment of 400 Dalasis!. In my case, I did not notice the receipt until I had paid the 400 Dalasis...too late sucker! Mysteriously, I was given a sticker to enter a privately owned exotic animal zoo on the highway outside of the park as a consolation. These "proprietors" apparently figured out an arrangement with the owners of the zoo to sell entry to that separate enterprise, off-site, under the guise that it was a mandatory fee to enter the Reserve. I was then asked for another 100 Dalasis to rent a pair of binoculars with no strap. I later found that the 10 X 50 glasses had been dropped and damaged so that the mirror prisms inside had been knocked out of alignment rendering them useless. Inasmuch as they were extremely heavy and without a strap, I simply pitched them into my sack and carried on with my own self-guided walk through the pathways of the Reserve. I respectfully declined the extremely high pressure mandatory but voluntary but mandatory requirement to hire a guide for another 300 Dalasis because I did not want to be accompanied by an unofficial "guide" who knew nothing about the faunna, flora and wildlife except what one could see anyway with the naked eye. The last thing I wanted was someone talking to me incessantly for the duration of my experience which did turn out to be a very beautiful 2-hour stroll through a luxurious forest full of wildlife. About halfway into the Park, I came across the remains of the Darwin Biodiversity Field Station which is adorned with old rotting posters and two bumsters dressed in disco garb and sunglasses who, not surprisingly, were requesting more "donations." They presented a "guestbook" that was undated, but appeared to be signed by people who were donating up to 500 Dalasis for a project that unknownst to them was terminated in 2005. The donation box was not only unlocked, but it had disappeared with the slot simply allowing the money to fall on the floor. When I asked who would get the money, the "boys," probably in their late 20s, stated that the money would go to "the man." The station had some displays of bones that the boys had collected in the forest, lying on a table, and the remnants of old biodiversity exhibits. This field station offered no information about what was going on in the park. Notably, no one in the park, at the entrance or at this field station, could sell me a simple map of the park. For all the come-ons for money, one would have thought the easiest sell would have been a map of the park itself so that patrons like myself could find their way around the winding pathways, as obvious as they are. But then, enabled with a map, who would need a guide? This was a very simple thing to prepare and distribute for which I would have paid gladly. The absence of maps was designed to compel the purchase of a guide. Who wants foreign visitors to have a pleasant walk through the park on their own? Certainly the owners don't. Nevertheless, continuing on from the field station, I had an extremely pleasant experience noting crocodiles, many more exotic birds than I had anticipated, and plenty of monkeys. It truly is a beautiful experience if you would like to take a walk for a couple of hours on your own. At all costs, however, I would avoid the sucker plays of everyone who is offering you something for money, especially their delightful company and incessant banter while you are trying to listen to the nature and take it all in. Near end of the pathway on the interior of the park there is what appears to be a legitimate zoo which contains hyenas, baboons and wild monkeys. These animals are kept in these cages on the explanation that they were once domesticated and the proprietors are attempting to allow them to re-adapt to their natural environment. They would be released in six months. I cannot imagine who would have domesticated the hyenas that I saw in those cages. They were huge! Domesticated baboons? Finally, the exit trail leads you onto, of all place, the main highway far from your starting point. There you will find the UK owned zoo that contains some exotic animals outside of their natural habitat such as lions and cheetahs. Although I had unwittingly been forced to pay for entry into the Reserve, I passed on the idea, walked down the driveway onto the main highway, and then walked about three quarters of a kilometer down the highway to reunite with my vehicle at the entry of the park. It seemed an odd configuration to enter at one end, and then be dumped onto a main highway only to walk along noisy and fierce traffic to get back to your starting point. In the end, I did enjoy the walk and the exposure to nature that I found there. I'm afraid, however, that the fact that it has been spoiled by fraudulent tricks and and parasitic squatters who have taken over a once well-maintained biodiversity project assured me that I would not return to this place. Left alone, it is a beautiful place. Unfortunately, it has been spoiled by the unnatural. There are many other better maintained or unmaintained nature reserves in The Gambia that are well worth my time and money. Be warned!

reviews.title: eagle heights
reviews.text: went to abuko to a place called eagle heights,this is owned by English,they do flying displays and are very informative,but their main aim is conservation ang getting wildlife back into gambia,we did a walk with ba ba the lion cub which was amazing so please visit and support wildlife is dying out

reviews.title: Saw some amazing wildlife.
reviews.text: Hired our own guide for a walk around this very manageable wildlife park. Saw some memorable sights including crocodiles, pygmy bee eaters, fire-finches and an African darter. There is a rather sad zoo towards the rear of the park where there are one or two sorry looking hyenas and baboons but I understand that the plan is to improve this facility in conjunction with the near-by Eagle Heights Park which is also worth a visit.

reviews.title: wildlife Gem
reviews.text: This is a huge nature park. It has fascinating flora and fauna. If you are a nature lover with an interest in birds, it's a must! We were lucky enough to see two species of Deer and crocodiles - spotted by our eagle eyed bird guide, Ansu Dunor. I cannot recommend him highly enough. He was very patient with us and wished to ensure we saw as much as possible. Beware of fake guides - to ensure a good guide, we recommend you ask for Ansu at the Bird Watchers Association located next to the Bridge in Kotu.

reviews.title: Something Old something New
reviews.text: This new nature site is at Abuko Nature Reserve,it is called EAGLE   Heights it says"face to face with nature" and so it is the people want to try and bring back some of the animals that Human beings over the years have destroyed eg Cheetars, (they have a cub) brings tears to your eyes.Lions, different birds  of prayand so much more, but they need our help so please visit and see what they have done in a short time, there are toilets, some benches under trees to drink cold Coke, water etc.

reviews.title: Very Highly Recommended
reviews.text: Excellent and very knowledgeable guide Ismaela showed us many animals and kept us save as he walked with us around the park.  He took us on a long tour and allowed us to borrow his binoculars to view the crocodiles and kingfishers around the water.  We also saw vultures, ospreys, termite mounds, bushbuck antelopes and inside the Eagle Heights Centre (which is within the Abuko Nature Reserve) we saw baby vultures, tortoises, birds of prey, a lion cub called Babar and even a cheetah couple!  Very educational and the conservation work they are doing here is excellent.  The animals are very well looked after and if any are in cages this is only ever for breeding or rehabilitation purposes.

reviews.title: was so peaceful
reviews.text: was so peaceful and amazing all at the same time worth a visit, for a tour and culture and traditions and seeing the baboo's

reviews.title: Loved it!
reviews.text: A real feel of African wild life. Animal sighting and nature- great way to spend your day if you're bored of sitting by the pool (don't get me wrong, I still got a tan that day). At times it look like scenes from Lost. Would do it again!

reviews.title: Abuko
reviews.text: Rather run down and avaricious staff. Over rated: we were taken to far better bird watching sites than this one, well regarded as it once was.

reviews.title: Worth a visit if you are a bird watcher
reviews.text: We had no interest whatsoever in the orphanage, only going for the birds. We hired a guide locally and spent a pleasant few hours walking around the reserve and added quite a few birds to our list. We also saw colobus and green vervet monkeys plus a couple of crocs. Maybenot worth visiting if you are not Into birdwatching, though the walk is pleasant enough.

reviews.title: Waste of time
reviews.text: Arrived here early afternoon. As we didn't have much time, our driver wanted to drive us to the center to see the hyenas & feed the monkeys. We have been a few times in the past, many years ago & had a good time, although I was never too keen on the condition the animals were kept in. We were taking friends out for a day & thought it would be nice to visit. On arrival our driver asked about the price & said we just wanted to drive straight into the centre. He was told its 400 d each!!!! And we had to take a guide for the walk through the forest. I understand this is the guides only mean of income but we didn't want to do the walk, we've never had this problem before. We explained we only wanted to see the center but was told we had to do all if it so we got back in the car. The man came over & said ok what will you pay for what you want to do. I said it's too late, as he was being greedy we would just go to lamin lodge for a drink. Bad luck, you lose out. Some other friends of ours did visit, on my recommendation (from past experiences) they said it was extremely overpriced, the animals were in appalling conditions & overall it was rubbish. Sorry guys, had I known how badly it had gone down hill & how expensive it was I would have told them not to bother. Stick to the crocodile pond at 50d each.

reviews.title: Beautiful nature walk
reviews.text: The walk is wonderful, shame there were too many noisy tourists scaring the crocs away! A guide named Billy had excellent knowledge, I felt it a real Shame that these guides are not employed by the park which is government owned & it's quite expensive compared to other tourist attractions in Gambia, so it was shocking to me that Billy only got paid the tips! There was a very wounded hyena which was a little concerned, apparently he had fought with the others. All other animals seemed happy & healthy. Eagle heights is very new & therefore they don't have many animals to see but the staff are very knowledgeable.

reviews.title: A must see
reviews.text: A great way to see animals in rehabilitation, be prepared for the long walk through the forest. There are Cheetahs, crocodiles, birds, hawks, monkeys etc to see, worth a visit.

reviews.title: Vile disgusting place
reviews.text: This part is written for the government own part of the so called nature reserve. We went with Thomas cook who had advertised it as a National park and Animal orphanage. Never seen animals is such appalling conditions, no clean water, Hyenas that were so mange ridden it must of been awful for them in the heat. A monkey in a cage that was paralyzed from the waist down, had to drag himself to the food, asked the keepers who lied and said it only arrived the previous day, which later was found not to be true it had been like it for over a month, I offered to pay for the vet to come out and humanly put it to sleep!!!!!!!. It is not an orphanage it is cruelty beyond belief. !!!!!!!

reviews.title: Recomend this attraction
reviews.text: When you have paid in you feel a little pressure to put more money in the donation box and the man at the gate follows you and show this to you which i think is unnecessary. apart form this it is well worth the visit.

reviews.title: Amazing if you're a Birder
reviews.text: Easy to get to by Taxi from Banjul.  Good number of Gambian Bird Species and mammals.  Well run with guides available.  Early morning or late afternoon visits are essential to have the best birding experience.

reviews.title: A vast improvement at Abouko.
reviews.text:
New look Abouko. 
03 November 2014, 15:29
Lovely to see Abouko Park has been taken over by some responsible people,now renamed Eagle Heights,it puts on flying displays each morning,various new animals are presant including Leopards and baby lions and various raptors,its being well run and the animals are being well cared for,theres a new refreshments area and a nice shady lodge where you can now view the various activities,most important the various indigenous animal species will,overtime,be introduced back into the park,details are on FB.

03 November 2014, 15:34
Eagle Heights Gambia is NOW OPEN! 

Eagle Heights Gambia is based at the beautiful Abuko Nature Reserve in The Gambia, West Africa. Set among almost 500 acres you will be entranced by the flora and fauna around you. 

Currently at the Centre are our 2 Cheetah with which we are hoping to begin a successful breeding project. A selection of Birds of Prey including a Crowned Eagle, Lanner Falcon, Tawny Eagle and Bateleur Eagle! 

The current orphanage inside Abuko will be collaborating with us enabling us to move the Hyena from their current enclosure to a new and improved version. This also applies to the Baboons and any other animals that arrive at the orphanage from now on. 

Daily Talks will take place along with a flying demonstration. You will also be invited to take a pit stop at our Bar for an all important refreshment!

Following the opening of the centre we will then begin our second project, Reintroduction! We will be reintroducing many once indigenous species back into the Abuko Buffer Zone. These are species that once lived there naturally but were unfortunately wiped out by humans etc.

reviews.title: Superb!
reviews.text: Set In a dry rainforest there is much to see here, many birds of which there are too many to name an in terms of mammals if you arrive early and go to the hide that looks over the small lake you have a high chance of seeing vervet monkey, red colobus monkey, bushbuck, sun squirrel and if lucky sitatunga! There are also a pair of resident nile crocodiles that inhabit the lake.. You can see many of the kingfisher species here aswell as palm nut vulture, violet turaco, hammerkop and a few hornbill species! Small fee to get in but if you have a good guide the cost of your guide normally means they pay for you! At the end of the trail at Abuko there is a woodland bar where you can get close to the vervet monkeys but don't get too close as a scratch or bite could lead to worse! By the bar is an animal orphanage of injured wild animals in recovery including baboons, Patas monkey and spotted hyena

reviews.title: Great Birding Venue
reviews.text: Anyone visiting here should be well aware of its birding heritage, what I would say is hire a good reputable guide. I have visited twice although the first visit yielded a good array of birdlife the second visit was much more productive mainly down to the guide.

reviews.title: Not much to see
reviews.text: We went to this park with taxi and spent there maybe 2-3 hours. We had a guide and it was useless. There weren't many animals or much to see. Day was really hot in February (47 celcius ) There are better places to go in Gambia so i don't recommend this place :)

reviews.title: Uninteresting
reviews.text: I visited this park in June and found nothing interesting. We saw a few monkeys roaming free, but the rest of the animals were caged. As we approached the area, there was a small alligator in one of the cages. It went half-crazy and, in three hits, broke the fence and escaped into the forest. That little anecdote was the most interesting part of our visit. It's also worth mentioning that at several tourist spots we went to, they tend to not have money to give you change when it's time to pay.

reviews.title: Very interesting
reviews.text: We went at the wrong time of the day (11.00am) so we were still walking through Reserve at midday and beyond (takes about 2 hours).  It was very hot but we survived and enjoyed the experience very much.  If you don't like the heat (or monkeys jumping out of the bushes at you!) don't got at the height of the day.

reviews.title: Nature reserve
reviews.text: We went here as part of our group bird watching tour, out guide was very good and we was able to see a lot of different birds, we did other animals as well including monkeys. We didn't really like the conditions the hyenas were kept in the cages seemed small and they were quite dirty.

reviews.title: only forest and catastrophic guide
reviews.text: At the entrance, we were quoted a price that would make any zoo in Europe look cheap. With the help of our Gambian friend, we managed to get the price down. The guide had to be booked separately. He ran ahead and we followed behind. The pace was breathtaking; we soon had to carry the children. After about half an hour, he told us, "Caution: don't carry children because of the green mambas." "Hello, does it take half an hour for him to notice?" At the end, one child was attacked by a monkey.

reviews.title: nothing interesting, animals in poor condition
reviews.text: Big disappointment. A couple of monkeys, half of them locked in cages. One monkey was locked in a very small cage, which made you feel sorry for it. The hyenas weren't in good condition either. The park isn't set up for tourists. One bar was closed, only one was open where you could buy a Coca-Cola. Nothing else. Free monkeys appear there, and you can give them peanuts. They are also found in other places. Well, I don't recommend it for people who like animals, because you'll leave sad. I can't say they're starving, but the conditions are bad.

reviews.title: beautiful but quite small nature park
reviews.text: The Abuko Nature Reserve is a beautiful park, but don't expect a wealth of wildlife like you'll find in parks in East and South Africa. There are plenty of birds and monkeys, but no large mammals.

reviews.title: Видели крокодила
reviews.text: Мне парк очень понравился. На кассе пытаються втюрить экскурсовода, от услуг которых мы вежливо отказались, так как хотели погулять вдвоем. Билет стоит в районе 40 далласи. Мы с собой зяли нашего таксиста, чтобы он не скучал в машине, Для местных вход еще дешевле, около 15 далласи. В парке мы видели крокодила, много разных обезьян, интересные деревье. Я рекомендую, идти в парк с самого утра, так как можно встретить большее количество животных, которые после обеда прячутся. Цены на напитки в парке умеренные, можно купить арахис и бананы, чтобы покормить обезьян, но лучше взять это с собой.

reviews.title: Much better than Bijilo
reviews.text: The only place where we hired a guide, the visit is worth it. We saw crocodiles, antelopes, many monkeys, squirrels, vultures, and other birds. They also have hyenas, caged, as we were told, as part of a rehabilitation project for these animals. It was truly impressive to see them in action. We arrived just as they were being fed, and they were laughing and circling like crazy.

reviews.title: Great park, I enjoyed the trip
reviews.text: Lot of serious birders wandering around with massive cameras, the best place to see all sorts of birds, there is a small lake that attracts all sorts of birds and a few hides scattered around. They have Hyenas who are to fat to even chase the vultures away from pinching their food, never seen such fat animals. Also caged baboons. The keeper told me most of these animals have been rescued from bad homes. I was concerned about a very skinny Baboon but I was told he was taken from a soldier who was not looking after him. They certainly do their best to look after the animals. Refreshments in the center of the park with some seats in the shade, that was nice. I enjoyed the day, would recommend a visit

reviews.title: I expected more
reviews.text: For such a big space I was expecting to see more animals. Our guide was great and very informative but the lack of animals was disappointing and I'm sure we walked a couple of hours. Apart from the two types of monkey that were roaming about (one type was the same as the ones that come to the hotel) the others were caged, the hyenas were just lying about because of the heat, the crocodiles were nowhere to be seen, and I saw one exotic looking bird (apart from the caged parrot)! They said they were getting more animals in soon but it wasn't a very exciting walk unfortunately, but to be fair its not their fault that the animals were hiding, not around and tired.

reviews.title: Abouko......Disgraceful
reviews.text: This must be one of the most neglected parks I've ever seen, its got worse over the past 3 years. The caged animals are in a pitiful state. The baboon troop has dwindled from 40 animals to a handful,there kept in a bare cage,in another sparse cage was a vulture with a live monkey for company it was obviously the birds food! In the same cage last year was a giant tortoise and a pelcan, no sign of those and seeing the conditions they lived in I fear the worse . The Hyenas were in an awful state, one was surrounded by vultures and it was obvious he was sick. Stay away if you are an animal lover or you will leave this hell hole in tears.

reviews.title: Birders paradise;think again
reviews.text: This park like all the other parks we visited has been seriously neglected despite staff who sit about all day doing nothing. It is in need of signs; the lavatories need cleaning up and  like all parks geared for birdwatching it needs the provision of water so that birds can be observed.

reviews.title: Not much to see. Guides useless
reviews.text: Went to Abuko Nature Reserve with good intentions, and was met by a guide that wanted 400 D for a tour (ended up with 300 D) and gave the impression it was manditory with a guide (it is not). He talked a little about the history of the park and the trees. Walked around paths with trees, bushes, a few birds, monkees and butterflies. Ended up at the orphanage with monkees and hyenas in cages. Dissapointing experience. If you go don't take a guide.

reviews.title: Maybe need to go early in the morning?
reviews.text: There are mixed reviews for this park. We went late morning and were disappointed: little to see, some caged hyenas, self appointed guide, aggressive monkeys (not like Bijolo). Maybe the higher ratings are for early morning when there is more bird life? We saw four birds only. It takes two hours to walk around the one forest path.

reviews.title: Nothing to see
reviews.text: Well, we really didn't see anything else than the caged animals (poor hyenas, one was in a really small cage, baboons and turtles). In the beginning the quide (who invited himself with us) told that we probably aint going to see any animals.. cause they are sleeping or eating or what ever. And we really didn't see anything, not even birds. We walked for an hour in the "jungle". There was a "crocodile pool" where was supposed to be 50 or something crocodiles, didn't see any, and nobody else has seen. Welt kind of like cheated, had to pay for the quide too. Felt bad cause of the caged animals. Aint gonna visit Abuko never again.

reviews.title: Nothing to see, apart from some caged Hyenas and Baboons - hassle from sellers
reviews.text: Went here on a trip out, expecting to see hundreds of varieties of birds. Saw less than 10.
