Paid the entrance fee, was then followed by a manager who asked for a donation for food - anything from 200 to 400D, I do not know what they spend the money on as there seems to be nothing here that they need to feed, apart from a few rescue animals (and only a few!). After a walk around, there is a visitors center - where on entering you feel instantly pressured into buying a t-shirt or other souvenirs. About half way around there is a shop, and some people selling wood carvings. You cannot sit and have a drink here without being hassled into buying a wood carving. If you buy from one seller you then get hassled by the other seller to buy from them too as they need to money to buy food!. On exiting there are a number of wood carving stalls that you have to pass. The sellers come at you from all over - one dragged me to his stall by my arm and told me that he had not had any breakfast and asked if I would buy a simple darning for 'only 300D' so he could buy breakfast. DO NOT BUY FROM ONE OF THESE PRESSURE SELLERS OR THEY WILL ALL COME AFTER YOU FOR A SALE. On leaving the reserve, there are another two locals who will try and sell you chilled drinks for an upmarket price of D75 (they were only D20 in my hotel). Was a terrible day out, it would be a bit better if they cleared all the wood carving sellers away - or only let one or two sell - not around 10 that you have to pass on your way out, all selling the same things.

reviews.title: Do Not Go
reviews.text: Went here on a recent trip to gambia. Don't bother, not much to see but trees and the animals are kept in horrendous conditions, so who knows where the donations go.

reviews.title: Abuko
reviews.text: A lovely walk through the forest, with a pond where crocodiles live and a monkey sanctuary! There were also two hyenas.

reviews.title: Hardly any 'wild' animals spotted
reviews.text: We were actually a bit disappointed with this park. The only "free" animals we saw were the same monkeys you can see in Monkey Park (Bilijo Park), so if you have to choose, go for Monkey Park (there are ten times as many)! The other animals (baboons, hyenas, a rare vulture, and tortoises) were in cages that were far too small, and you can also see them at the zoo. Entrance: 30 dalasi (€0.60). Another downside: at the entrance, a man was asking for donations for the park, but even our local guide advised us against it because you don't know where your money will end up.

reviews.title: Great Reserve, Wally Faal, Great Guide
reviews.text:
I arranged this with expert bird guide Wally Faal (wallyfaal@yahoo.com).

We had quite the adventure and Wally really knows the Reserve and his birds.

When we went, Wally did not have his own vehicle, but he adjusted his rate and we all took a taxi.

reviews.title: Niestety nudny park
reviews.text: Ten park niestety trochę nudny mało małp i zwierząt polecam zdecydowanie park Bijilo. W Bijilo więcej zwierząt i duża frajda z małpami

reviews.title: Wonderful
reviews.text: Hotel needs a little tlc , but look pass that and u would have a wonderful holiday , staff were so friendly and we had a laugh with lot of them , and went out with one of the staff for the day , good ok , pool kept nice and clean by ( chicken legs ha ha ) he was a great laugh, pa for fishing trip (great day out ) and well pa in side bar he crazy and so much fun ,ok to go to town the boy do wait out side hotel but you can just say no thank you , we didn't and they carry yr shopping and tell u about the town ( all they ask is a English pound , that's cheap to learn a lot . Great hoilday all round . Food ok .

reviews.title: Beautiful nature reserve
reviews.text: Make sure you get here early in the morning. It's still quiet then, the animals are more active, and you'll be less bothered by mosquitoes. Take a guide with you. They'll tell you about the plants and animals in the park and are also excellent birdwatchers. Binoculars are also a good idea. We were here later in the day. You won't see any crocodiles then, and you'll need to protect yourself from mosquitoes. It's a lovely walk through the forest with lots of birds and monkeys.

reviews.title: After visiting the zoo...cool off with Jungle Man
reviews.text: The African Zoo is just another experience you can have in Gambia. You'll feel like you're in the jungle, and you can feed the monkeys peanuts! There are vultures, birds, and other creatures. Right in front of the African Zoo is Jungle Man. He'll offer you ice-cold refreshments, and you can enjoy a pleasant chat with him, enjoying the exotic setting over a drink. He loves to display the little flags brought to him by guests and will engage you in pleasant conversation. Be careful during the rainy season! Wear mosquito repellent, because you'll feel like you're in the jungle!

reviews.title: Take a guide for a small fee
reviews.text: Nice walks in the forests with plenty of wildlife. We had a guide to take us around which was great. Very informative. I have visited here twice and enjoyed both visits.

reviews.title: Worth a visit - make sure you get a good guide.
reviews.text: We had a mixed visit, in that there were no animals around (apart from one or two monkeys and some beautiful birds). However, we got lucky with our guide (sorry I can't remember his name) who was really informative and very knowledgable. He was able to talk passionately for the whole walk, which took a couple of hours. The animal orphanage is interesting, and you're guaranteed to see baboons, hyenas and lots and lots of vultures there - even if they are behind wire fences. Try to go if you're in the area - if only to support the business and the cause. Apparently early morning is the best time to see the animals.

reviews.title: As Gambia once was
reviews.text: A lovely park to explore as part of an excursion; be sure to bring a good guide who can point out the animals and other interesting facts you'll encounter. The animals are in their natural habitat (except, of course, those in cages), and the park is reminiscent of Gambia as it must have been before it was bombed. You can see various species of monkeys and birds here.

reviews.title: Outstanding
reviews.text: We had a knowledgable and attentive guide for the day who found and identified scores of birds for us. The Brewer viewing hide was fantastic and the whole experience perfect.

reviews.title: small but cool
reviews.text: Visited the bird sanctuary around noon. Didn't see many birds :-), but it's a pleasant sanctuary, with several cages in the middle containing monkeys, hyenas, turtles, and pelicans.

reviews.title: Interesting but very quiet
reviews.text:
We went on a day excursion from a cruise ship in Banjul.
The demo of palm tree climbing, juice tapping and the walk through the forest was interesting, but only worth doing on the basis of "we aren't likely to be coming to this part of The Gambia again". The constant demand for tips can be very wearing, though.

reviews.title: Hardly worth a visit
reviews.text: I made one of my Gambian friends take me here last year. There was little to see in return for a long walk in the heat. The guide insisted that we needed him, but hardly gave any information and neither the entry fee nor the guide's fee were cheap.

reviews.title: The Animal Orphanage needs some financial help
reviews.text: Second visit to this lovely natural place, great for birds and walking as mentioned previously - however the small animal orphanage as it is called within this place needs financial help from what I can see. There are some Hyenas in a large cage however hidden next to the pelican is another cage with some very poorly looking Hyenas with troubles etc, I'm not judging but from what I understand, this place needs some help to make sure the animals are cared for more, ie more food, medical help for animals and better quality of surroundings that they live in day after day. The baboons could do with ropes and tires hanging and things to amuse them and play with for example. As its mainly tourists that visit this place, they could increase the entrance fee which could help. I may have ideas as to how this could be improved and would love to be able to help in someway. That said, the wild monkeys are used to people and they will come and see you especially if you buy monkey nuts and will gently take them out of your hand which is a fantastic experience and one of the main reasons I visit the place.

reviews.title: Great if you like wildlife & walking
reviews.text: Great chance to see some of The Gambia's wildlife but be prepared for 2hrs of walking in a wood/forest  If you go without a guide there are guides hanging around the entrance and they vary from very good to rubbish Unless you know the birds it can be difficult to chose a competent one.  I've had "guides" describe birds as little brown jobs and others that not only correctly identify but give you Latin names as well now that's just showing off!  Ask for a try before you buy  agree a price and get them to walk with you for 10 mins  and let them show you the birds you'll soon know what you've got  You can go it alone as it is difficult to get lost just follow the path but the good guide will show you so much more than you'll see going it alone and are well worth the 400D fee for their services

reviews.title: Rustig park, pinda's voeren aan apen.
reviews.text:
We went here after visiting the Serrekunda market and then you notice how peaceful it is
If you are there for birds you can get a guide with binoculairs. If you are not don't think they are freebies and say no.
After paying the fee and entering the park another man comes up with a donation form for maintenance on the park. They should include that in the ticket price and don't hassle on every opportunity.

We spotted some beautiful trees and we came across some monkeys. (we dont have the expert eye for birds so we didnt notice them) Also some termite hills.
Somewhere halfway there were some animals caged up. Baboons, 2 pelicans, a turtle and some hyena's.
The smaller monkeys run around and you can buy a bag of peanuts there to feed them. (about 25D for a bag) The bigger ones come pick them out of your hand and they can be quite greedy so you have to throw some around for the smaller ones to also enjoy some.

More walking ahead you come through a souvenir area.

This trip is for you if you like to walk a small hour and like to see some nature and animals.

Afterwards we also stopped at the nearby goat and sheep market.

reviews.title: Still as interesting as it was 40 years ago!
reviews.text: I lived in The Gambia in the 1970s, and spent every Sunday morning walking around the nature reserve, mainly birdwatching. It is such a pleasure to return so many years later and find it almost unchanged, though sadly they need more funding to keep things going. The highlight is watching the birds from the upstairs viewing area in the large building next to the lake, which also has crocodiles. Take your binoculars and you will see so many different species! Then the walk through the forest is fascinating, so many different trees, and with luck you will see plenty of monkeys, both the Callithrix and the Red Colobus monkeys. They are easy to spot as they scamper through the trees, and trees with have fruit are often absolutely full of monkeys! Unfortunately I didn't spot a monitor lizard on this visit, though there are many large lizards in the park, and snakes too, though the reptiles are much more active during the rainy season. Halfway round the walk you reach the animal orphanage, which is a very sad sight with monkeys and baboons in enclosures, when they should be roaming wild. It's all very dilapidated and makes you feel sorry for the animals. At the end of the walk round there is a craft market, not very good I'm afraid, so it's better to hurry straight through!

reviews.title: animals also have the right to a good life
reviews.text: This park isn't really worth a visit. The scenery is okay, with the occasional monkey, but a group of baboons living in a much-too-small cage, one of which is kept in a kind of large crate somewhere behind the pelicans (who are also locked in a cage without water) because he's gone mad (according to one of the guides), and two groups of hyenas also forced to live in filthy surroundings without water are simply unacceptable. Don't go there, and if you love animals, don't even go near it because it's heartbreaking. I will definitely do everything in my power to get these animals out of there.

reviews.title: Lovely nature reserve (its not a zoo!)
reviews.text:
Abuko is a wonderfully intact piece of tropical forest, amongst the otherwise heavily populated Serrekunda area. Some reviewers seem to be under the impression this a zoo, it's not! There is a small animal orphanage at one end of the reserve but its a desperately sad place and not a reason to visit.

I enjoyed wandering the narrow paths seeing birds, lizards and monkeys (you will see them if you walk slowly and quietly). The Darwin field centre is an excellent vantage point to see lots of wading birds and birds of prey as well as Nile Crocodiles.

The guides are knowledgeable and well worth taking along on an initial visit. I agree with the previous reviewer who advised taking water with you, it's quite a long way to do the full reserve circuit and the heat is sapping. The reserve doesn't get much funding so facilities are basic, but I loved it for being so quiet without lots of other people around.

I would recommend Abuko more to the serious nature lover who will get more from it than someone who expects to be entertained and see an animal every 2 minutes. For me, taking time was rewarded by getting to see amazing species like the Giant Kingfisher close up. I enjoyed it so much I actually went twice during my week in The Gambia.

reviews.title: Good for bird spotters
reviews.text: A pleasant outing, with lots of opportunities to spot fantastic bird life in the mature undergrowth. Our guide was knowledgeable but a bit uninspiring. We were sorry we didn't see crocs from the lookout point across the pool, and were disappointed and saddened by the dirty-looking 'animal orphanage' - even if they did have hyenas and pelicans. The refreshment point was a bit dull, leaving us exposed to the entrances of the stallholder nearby.

reviews.title: A cancelled trip
reviews.text: I had booked Birds and Breakfast in England before I read a TripAdviser review which said it would be better to go to Abuku with a specialkist guide. The trip was cancelled so I followed advise from TripAdviser and had the most wonderful time using a local professional guide. I also discovered The University of Warwick (probably LifeSciences) have been working at Abuku for some years as part of a research programme. The little booklets are excellent and well worth the money.

reviews.title: Take a drink with you
reviews.text:
It's very hot take some water with you.
Lots to see as you walk with your guide.
Binoculars were a God send.

reviews.title: definitely worth a trip but probably just the once is enough...
reviews.text: we visited abuku in january with our 7 year old son, he loved it once we had actually found where the animals were, they kept the animals quite far from the entrance to the park, we declined the guide and walked a massive circle for nearly an hour to arrive back at the entrance having found nothing, we got our directions then took another 20 minute walk into the bush (get the guide at the entrance its worth it) we eventually came to 2 large enclosures one with lots of baboons going wild for the nuts we had purchased to feed them and another breed of monkey in the other and green monkeys all around us roaming free with the escapee (a baby baboon that refused to go back into the enclosure) i think there was around 5 different species of monkey/baboons in total as well as a monitor lizard we had passed on the way in.. after our talk from the keeper she guided us over to the final enclosure where the hyenas were having an afternoon nap, they were huge and there was also vultures in the enclosure, my boy was mesmerised,....... after a rest stop at the tuck shop for ice cold drinks we haggled ourselves a nice bargain on a wood carved ornament and headed our way to the exit... all in all was a very memorable day and so glad we went however it is not very interesting until the final moments of the park when you reach the animals.... am i glad i went? yes definitely and would recommend it too, but only once! so will i be returning? in a word,,, no.

reviews.title: where are the animals?
reviews.text: Abuko is no more what it used to be. Only few animals, everthing in a bad condition. Since the "president" Jammeh moved the most interesting animals to his private zoo in Kanilai, Abuko has lost many of its attractions. Nobody would officially admit, but this is what happened. So if you want to see a lion, better visit your local zoo :-(

reviews.title: Good few hours out
reviews.text: Good outing for a few hours to pass the time but not a great deal to do, was talked about that Abuko would be getting a revamp but nothing as yet.

reviews.title: Good for short holiday.
reviews.text: Small National Reserve inside the urban life. Suitable to chose for short holidays.

reviews.title: Wonderful experience
reviews.text:
The monkeys appearing from no where and stealing nut from you.
Some of them even perched on my wife's head

reviews.title: Abuko Nature Reserve
reviews.text: Saw lots of different monkey along with the hyena's - different spieces of plants on the walk around the forest, went a couple of times at different times of day, many vultures when I went around 6.pm and they were feeding the hyena's!!

reviews.title: The beginnings of a "gambian" "rspc to local wildlife!?!
reviews.text: The reserve offers a closer encounter with some of The Gambias more illusive wildlife,fab` for all bird watching,in the morn and evening.Adventurous bumpy sandy tracks getting there and daunting sign posting,best way is go for a sensible wander unless looking for fancier hobbies-then hire a guide,the wildlife is natural and well camoflaged.If tipping,give direct to office for animals feed etc not the guides,them got a relative salary!!!

reviews.title: There are few exotic animals that can be visited in Gambia.
reviews.text: In my humble opinion, it's a thousand times more interesting to meet Gambians.

reviews.title: Monkeys!!
reviews.text: Don`t miss this park on your trip to The Gambia-so much fun. The monkeys are very friendly-not vicious at all. They climb up you, sit on your shoulders etc as you feed them monkey nuts. So many monkeys!  Book the trip with the RSPB men on Bakau beach (under white umbrella by Calypso Restaurant) if you want to enjoy spotting the birds as well as well as knowledge of the local monkeys. If not then go with the tour guides opposite the Ocean Bay Hotel. They charged us 20 quid which included the taxi & full mornings entertainment plus relaxing time sat under the African sun shades on the beautiful beach next to the park.

reviews.title: a must
reviews.text: great place for a day out ,dont forget your camera,great to have a guide to take you to the best locations

reviews.title: A little dissapointing
reviews.text: We spent about an hour here but overall were rather dissapointed, a nice walk through the forest, a couple of monkeys, and some sleeping hyenas, not much else!

reviews.title: Fantastic
reviews.text: Such a beautiful place to spend some time. We went in the early morning and only saw one other couple for the majority of the time we were there. However, on our way back out there were huge groups arriving. I would definitely recommend going independently with your own guide rather then with a tour company in a large group. We saw a huge variety of birds and there were certainly some very enthusiastic bird watchers there with all the high tech binoculars, telescopes, cameras etc. We also saw a couple of crocodiles and lots of monkeys. Halfway round there is an animal sanctuary where they house animals that have been removed from locals who have bought them to entertain tourists for a charge. There was a very friendly monkey that sat on my knee and played with my hair. You can buy peanuts to feed to the monkeys. We absolutely loved our time here and spent a good 3 hours wandering around spotting monkeys and birds. From what I remember it costs approx 50d (£1) each to get in.

reviews.title: Peacful, beautiful and easy to see the birdlife
reviews.text: My guide, Francis Gomez, led me through the reserve pointing out the local birdlife. Within minutes we had seen a dozen or more species I'd never seen before and over the three hours I was there, he was helpful, friendly and informative. He helped me see the species unique to the site which I probably would have missed without him. Admission to the reserve is very cheap but a guide will cost you about £20 upwards, depending how long you want to stay. Apart from the birds, there's a chance you might spot a croc and definitely monkeys.

reviews.title: Not very interesting
reviews.text: personally I was dissappointed, I did not see any wildlife except the caged ones and all i got was hassle from people trying to sell me woodcarvings. I found it boring an not as advertised. I would say go out and look around yourself and you see more but don,t rely on local bumsters to show you.

reviews.title: Beautiful but only for bird lovers
reviews.text: We arrived at Abuko having heard and read quite a lot about it. It is better to come here early in the morning, not around 11am like we did since most of the animals are sheltering from the heat and crocodiles are swimming closer to the bottom of the pond. The few monkeys we saw were not scared of humans, this is because they are used to humans feeding them. People say it was great to feed wild monkeys probably haven't been to a safari or national park before. Infact you are encouraged to buy peanuts for the monekys. And the zoo in the middle is apparently kept there so tourists can at least see something in the reserve if nothing else. It is expensive to run these reserves and you can see that in the health of the hyenas and monkeys. The place was grand back in the day with lion(s) and other animals, when the founder Mr. Brewster was alive but now has deteriorated a little. The president's zoo is better funded and has more animals. Saying that, we had a lovely walk around the area and saw some birds. Since we were not bird watchers or bird lovers, we just enjoyed the different varieties without knowing what they were :-)

reviews.title: A great day
reviews.text: We had a lovely time in Abuko, our guide was great and we saw loads of birds and monkeys... and even a snake! The one bad point is the awful 'zoo' in the middle where they house baboons, hyenas and turtles. It absolutely stinks and the animals are totally miserable. I refused to give any money for that.

reviews.title: Not worth a visit
reviews.text: What a shame this reserve has been allowed to go to rack and ruin.  Everything very shabby.  We were told that it used to be a wonderful place when it was first set up.  We saw very little and were very disappointed.

reviews.title: Great for the nost part...till you get to the animals in cages...
reviews.text: Although I thought Abuko was wonderful for the most part, (we saw a crocodile, a bushbuck and several species of monkeys and birds) I was dismayed to see the hyenas in captivity, also baboons and some other animals, all in cages. I was told that the baboons are orphaned (although it was a whole family), and also some of the other animals, but that the hyenas are just an exhibit. There also used to be a lion there but it escaped. Apparently they have links with the local zoo, and some of the animals live in captivity always. There is no need for this - visitors come to see wildlife in its natural state, not kept in a prison. The hyenas were pacing up and down ie exhibiting stereotypical behavior, which was not good to see at all. Also although there are notices up saying not to feed the wildlife however friendly it is, people (and one of the guides!) were openly feeding the monkeys peanuts, thus habituating the monkeys to humans, and causing them to lose their natural skills. Abuko should actively be fining people for doing this and the guides should be sufficiently educated so as not to do this. For this reason I have given this reserve a 3-star rating, otherwise it would be a 4 or 5.

reviews.title: The smell
reviews.text: It is a long walk with little of interest from the main gate to the first lodge which is twinned with the University of Warwick (Birdwatching), A bit interesting as an alligator was watching a wading bird and we watched the alligator...yawn!!... A short further walk through thicker overgrowth brings you to the heart of the reserve. Staff are always needing money to feed the animals... A very sad affair, as the main animals have allegedly been transported to the presidents old village zoo. You are left with the stench from 5 hyenas and 20 vultures who constantly watch the few monkeys that surround the area. There are a few captive monkeys to feed peanuts to if you want. Most fun was being professionally ambushed by the reserve monkeys on the way out who cleaned us of anything edible. in conclusion..It was tired, the staff were tired, the animals looked tired...

reviews.title: Monkey Loving!
reviews.text:
I loved Abuko, it has a little something for everyone. 

It is quite a walk, the less mobile may want to give this a miss, but when you get to the end, the tamer monkeys are there to entertain
and steal the nuts you have just bought for them! Keep the plastic bag out of slight or they will grab at it! 

It was fantastic to feed wild monekys. This made the trip well worth it. 

If you drove to the park, like I did, as a bit of advice, when you get to the cafe, go visit the hyenas and stuff, but don't go through the past with the exit sign over it. Go back the way you came, otherwise you end up a 15 minute walk down a dusty busy road from where you first started!!
